Cool to =
see the Kantei piece and yours in such close proximity, 
especially given t=
he motif similarities...  Nice guard.

> Hi Jim, all -

osting my thoughts on the latest (#3) tsuba kantei (Nobuiye)

hat the example tsuba reminded me of a tsuba of mine 
made by Jirotaro Naok=
atsu (shinshin-to swordsmith). Taking a look at

ther impressed with faithfulness that 
Naokatsu followed to reproduce the w=
ork of Nobuiye. I've posted a 
(less than quality?) photo of the Naokatsu f=
or you to see:

> 
> Notice the lumpy "bones" =
at the edge of the tsuba at 10 o'clock. 
Shodai Naokatsu added "bones" to t=
he surface of his tsuba and these 
can be seen at 1 o'clock and 5 o'clock p=
ositions. Notice the 
similar "plum blossom" design also used by him, no ex=
act, but 
similar to the Nobuiye. (My tsuba--about 88 mm--is slightly small=
er 
than the kantie Nobuiye. Mine is NBTHK papered.)
